column2: IPA: [ˈmurmənsk]) is a port city and the administrative center of Murmansk Oblast in the far northwest part of Russia. It sits on both slopes and banks of a modest ria or fjord
column3: Kola Bay
column4: an estuarine inlet of the Barents Sea. Its bulk is on the east bank of the inlet. It is in the north of the rounded Kola Peninsula which covers most of the oblast. The city is 108 kilometres (67 mi) from the border with Norway and 182 kilometres (113 mi) from the Finnish border. The city is named for the Murman Coast
column5: an archaic term in Russian for Norway.

column9: which elected a Presidium. Before this

column12: the All-Russian Central Executive Committee (VTsIK) issued two resolutions: "On the Establishment of Leningrad Oblast" and "On the Borders and Composition of the Okrugs of Leningrad Oblast"
column13: which transformed Murmansk Governorate into Murmansk Okrug within Leningrad Oblast and made Murmansk the administrative center of Murmansk Okrug.In 1934
column14: the Murmansk Okrug Executive Committee developed a redistricting proposal

column17: and west into Murmansk. While this plan was not confirmed by the Leningrad Oblast Executive Committee
column18: in 1935–1937 several rural localities of Kolsky and Polyarny Districts were merged into Murmansk anyway.According to the Presidium of the Leningrad Oblast Executive Committee resolution of February 26
column20: the administrative center of Polyarny District was moved from Polyarnoye to Sayda-Guba. However
column21: the provisions of the resolution were not fully implemented
column22: and due to military construction in Polyarnoye
column23: the administrative center was instead moved to Murmansk in the beginning of 1935. In addition to being the administrative center of Murmansk Okrug
column24: Murmansk continued to serve as the administrative center of Polyarny District until September 11
column27: when the VTsIK adopted a Resolution changing the administrative-territorial structure of Murmansk Okrug
column28: the city of Murmansk became a separate administrative division of the okrug

column31: they called Norwegenhafen for transportation of goods and raw materials from 1922–1941.

column2: Murmansk was a link to the Western world for the Soviet Union with large quantities of goods important to the respective military efforts traded with the Allies: primarily seeing military equipment
column3: manufactured goods and raw materials brought into the Soviet Union. The supplies were brought to the city in the Arctic convoys.German forces in Finnish territory launched an offensive against the city in 1941 as part of Operation Silver Fox. Murmansk suffered extensive destruction
column4: the magnitude of which was rivaled only by the destruction of Leningrad and Stalingrad. However
column5: fierce Soviet resistance and harsh local weather conditions with the bad terrain prevented the Germans from capturing the city and cutting off the vital Karelian railway line and the ice-free harbor.

column1: For the rest of the war
column2: Murmansk served as a transit point for weapons and other supplies entering the Soviet Union from other Allied nations. This resistance was commemorated at the 40th anniversary of the victory over the Germans in the formal designation of Murmansk as a Hero City on May 6
column3: 1985. During the Cold War Murmansk was a center of Soviet submarine and icebreaker activity. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union
column4: the nearby city and naval base of Severomorsk remains the headquarters of the Russian Northern Fleet.

The port of Murmansk remains ice-free year round due to the warm North Atlantic Current and is an important fishing and shipping destination. It is home port to Atomflot
column2: the world's only fleet of nuclear-powered icebreakers.The Port of Murmansk is the headquarters of Sevmorput (Northern Sea Route) and the administration of Russian Arctic maritime transport.

column1: Murmansk features a subarctic climate (Köppen Dfc)
column2: with long and cold winters and short
column3: cool summers. In the city
column4: freezing temperatures are routinely experienced from October to May. Average temperatures exceed 0 degrees Celsius only from May through October. The average low during the coldest part of the year in Murmansk is approximately −14 °C (7 °F). However
column5: temperatures routinely plunge below −20 °C (−4 °F) during the winter.

column2: with average highs in July exceeding +17 °C (63 °F). The city is slightly wetter during the summer than the winter and receives an annual average of just under 500 mm (20 in) of precipitation.

column1: The "midnight sun" is above the horizon from 22 May to 23 July (63 days)
column2: and the period with continuous darkness lasts a bit shorter
column3: polar night from 2 December to 10 January (40 days).

column5: set on January 6

column10: 1972.Murmansk has been affected by global warming in recent decades
column11: similar to other Arctic locations. For example
column12: December 2007 had an average high of 0.8 °C (33.4 °F)
column13: while a 2.3 °C (36.1 °F) average high was measured for March 2007. Summer has also been affected

column15: and a 24.3 °C (75.7 °F) average high during July 2018.
